summary: A confidential letter from lawyers representing a victim in the Epstein/Maxwell case to Judge Alison J. Nathan, requesting that all variations of their client's name be redacted from court papers ahead of Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal trial. The letter details previous failures in redaction that led to media exposure of their client in the UK, causing distress, and seeks assurances about proper anonymity protections moving forward.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Addressee of the letter; the judge overseeing Ghislaine Maxwell's upcoming criminal trial. The letter requests her to ensure proper redaction of the client's name.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the upcoming criminal trial. The letter is written by lawyers representing a different, unnamed client who is a victim and seeks redaction to avoid being associated publicly with Maxwell's case.

persons.name: Loretta Preska
persons.context: Previously granted an application to have the letter-writer's client's name redacted from court documents in a prior proceeding.

connections.description: The unnamed client represented by the letter's authors is identified as a victim, and the context implies Maxwell is the alleged perpetrator from a prior case.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the upcoming criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Preska previously granted a redaction application to protect the anonymity of the unnamed client.

events.title: Court Order for Redaction Requests
events.description: District Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order requiring any requests for redaction of documents to be submitted by April 21, 2021.

events.title: Prior Inadequate Redactions and Media Exposure
events.description: The unnamed client's name was previously released in court papers and published widely in the British press and online, causing distress, due to inadequate redaction procedures.

events.title: Successful Contempt Threats Against British Media
events.description: The client's lawyers successfully threatened British media with contempt proceedings, resulting in the removal of many publications identifying the client.

events.title: Upcoming Ghislaine Maxwell Criminal Trial
events.description: The letter is written in anticipation of the upcoming criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, prompting the request for strict redaction protocols.

locations: Thurgood Marshall United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: A victim in the Epstein/Maxwell case, represented by UK lawyers, is seeking anonymity ahead of Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal trial.
Previous redaction failures led to the client's name being published in British media, causing significant distress and requiring legal action to have content removed.
The client has a legal entitlement to lifelong anonymity in the United Kingdom under the Sexual Offences (Amendment) Act 1992.
The letter requests Judge Nathan to ensure all past and future court documents are properly redacted to protect the victim's identity.
The document highlights systemic issues and potential negligence in the court's document redaction processes for sensitive cases.
